item.title: Report X-2024081497
item.description:
Report X-2024081497

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-23T15:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-21
  • City: FAIRFIELD
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 8/21/2024 at approximately 0900, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 9327095 at the Ground facility in Fairfield, reporting an undeclared dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of four (4) 1-gallon containers packaged together in one fiberboard box. The package appeared damp on its topside. Further investigation revealed the inner containers, marked to match the label on the outside of the package, identifying the commodity as Xylenes, a fully regulated dangerous goods commodity. The shipment adorned no other markings, labeling, or paperwork. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

item.description:
Report X-2024081503

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-23T15:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-20
  • City: ROCKFORD
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: RESPONDED TO AN AIR PACKAGE THAT WAS LEAKED ON BY ANOTHER PACKAGE IN THE SORT. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY TWO KILOGRAMS OF DRY ICE PELLETS COOLING MEAT. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. OUTER BOX IS MARKED THIS SIDE UP, PERISHABLE, AND FREEZE OR REFRIGERATE UPON ARRIVAL. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

  • City: OXNARD
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Patrick Mier CHECKER/DRIVER REG called safety to report a HazMat spill in trailer 556479 UN2692, BORON TRIBROMIDE, 8 (6.1), PG I, POISON-INHALATION HAZARD ZONE B. Patrick stated he found the 4lbs box in the nose of the trailer and stated it looked like the box was crushed by other freight in transit . Patrick stated he was not to sure if the product was still in the container in the box or if it had leaked out in the trailer. Safety advised Patrick to stay clear of the box and the trailer until a team could arrive to assist with the spill. Patrick stated the trailer was empty and the box was on e of the last of the freight on the trailer. Patrick stated he set the box down on the table outside the trailer and will send a photo to safety. Patrick stated he does not know if anything in on the trailer floor and did not feel comfortable going back in the trailer.

  • Description: During sort operations at the MSPA location a fiberboard box was found with signs of a release. While investigating the shipment the spill agent found a glass bottle packaged with styrofaom molds top and bottom. The glas bottle was broken and all contents spilled inside of the fiberboard box. A packing slip inside identified the contents as dimethyl sulfoxide as a UN2810. There were no DG markings or paperwork on the outside of the fiberboard box. The shipment was placed into a steel salvage package and is being held at the location.

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-17
  • City: DORAL
  • State: FL

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS MIAMI FLORIDA FACILITY, ONE BLACK SHRINKED WRAPPED WOODEN SKID SHIPPING AIR CARGO SERVICE TO COLOMBIA WAS FOUND TO CONTAIN FLAMMABLE PRODUCTS. DURING THE SCREENING PROCESS WHILE CUTTING THE BLACK SHRINK WRAPPING, SEVERAL BOXES WERE FOUND WITH CLASS NINE DIAMOND LABELS AND AIR LIMITED QUANTITY MARKS. OTHER BOXES WERE FOUND WITH GROUND LIMITED QUANTITY MARKS. INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS OF THESE BOXES FOUND NUMEROUS FLAMMABLE PERFUMERY PRODUCTS. THE FREIGHT WAS OFFERED FOR AIR TRANSPORTATION TO UPS AIR CARGO WITHOUT ANY DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BLACK SHRINK WRAPPING. THERE WAS NO INDICATION ON THE AIR WAYBILL THAT DANGEROUS GOOD PRODUCTS WERE BEING SHIPPED AIR SERVICE. THE ISSUING CARRIER'S AGENT NAME AND CITY ON THE AIR WAYBILL IS ALSEATRANS US, 1665 NW 102ND AV, SUITE 108, MIAMI FL, 33172, US. THE SHIPPER'S NAME AND ADDRESS ON THE AIR WAYBILL IS MSL INTL GROUP, LLC, 1665 NW 102ND AV, MIAMI FL US.

item.title: Report E-2024080503
item.description:
Report E-2024080503

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-23T15:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-17
  • City: ROCKFORD
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: USPS PACKAGE WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING AT THE UPS FACILITY IN ROCKFORD, ILLINOIS. OUTER PACKAGE INSPECTION REVEALS ONE USPS PRIORITY MAIL BOX THAT HAS BEEN PARTIALLY DESTROYED WITH SEVERAL AEROSOL CANS OF SPRAYWAY GLASS CLEANER SPILLING OUT OF THE BOX. IT APPEARS THE CAPS OF ONE OR MORE OF THE AEROSOL CANS HAD COME OFF EXPOSING AND ENGAGING THE NOZZLE RELEASING THE PRODUCT INSIDE THE BOX. THE PACKAGE BEGAN TO DETERIORATE AND ULTIMATELY BROKE OPEN. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER USPS BOX TO INDICATE DANGEROUS GOODS WERE BEING SHIPPED. THE PACKAGE TRAILERED INTO THE UPS ROCKFORD FACLITY AND WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING PRIOR TO FLIGHT ON UPS AIRCRAFT. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report E-2024080515
item.description:
Report E-2024080515

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-23T15:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-12
  • City: SALT LAKE CITY
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-2ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that two (2) ounces of material was released due to a loose lid on one (1) 330-gallon poly tote. The loose lid was hand tightened and wiped clean with absorbent rags and then shipped onto the consignee. Clean Habor's personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and the spent absorbents were gathered and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum along with some impacted cardboard and PPE. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

I asked him to bring it to us while I retrieved the TCB. He brought it to the cdt galley where FA Vanak took pictures and went to the front to share them with the purser and captain. I placed the unit temporarily in the TCB without breaking the seal awaiting further instructions and checking the eFAOM. The unit was not hot or Ieaking. The Captain looked at the pictures and advised us to place in the TCB and monitor. I did so for the remaining 40 mins or so. We returned the battery to the passenger upon deplaning and advised him to dispose of it properly. We were advised by MX that since we did not need to break the seal on the zipper Of the TCB it could be returned to its stowed position.

The pallet containing 84 boxes with 2 each 1 gallon bottles inside collapsed& fell over. The pallet collapsing caused an estimated 10 gallons to spill on the dock. The spill was contained by dock associates. SEFL Safety was contacted, and contacted Hazmat 1 spill response. E3/OMI arrived on site at approximately 9:15. The team accessed the situation& proceeded with the clean up process. Clean up was complete at approximately 13:30. In total 10-55 gallon drums were used to contain the waste.E3/OMI will return to pick up the waste drums at a later date, once approval has been received.

item.title: Report X-2024081406
item.description:
Report X-2024081406

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-23T15:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-05
  • City: READING
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Operations Supervisor I Nathan ODonnell contacted safety to report that trailer 572156 caught on fire while on the 241/RDG yard. Operations Supervisor I Nathan ODonnell stated that after ABF Road Driver Terry Schreck arrived at 241/RDG the lead trailer 572156 started smoking. ABF Road Driver Terry S chreck advised that after he arrived at 241/RDG he was about to unhook his set when he noticed the lead trailer 572156 was smoking. ABF Road Driver Terry Schreck advised that he then proceeded to disconnect rear trailer 500713 and converter gear 71708 from the lead trailer. ABF Road Driver Terry Sch reck advised that he then proceeded to move trailer 572156 to the middle of the yard before he disconnected the trailer from tractor 13383. ABF Road Driver Terry Schreck advised that after he disconnected trailer 572156 from the tractor the Reading Fire Department arrived on scene. Deputy Chief Glor e of the Reading Fire Department advised that he believes a pallet of Lithium Ion Batteries shifted during transit. Deputy Chief Glore advised that the battery post may have contacted metal causing them to arc igniting a pallet of writing pens that were incased in carboard that was loaded underneath the pallet of Lithium Ion Batteries. Deputy Chief Glore advised that the Reading Fire Department was able to put the fire out and made sure no drains or waterways were impacted. Operations Supervisor I Nathan ODonnell advised he will send photos of the damage to safety. Safety contacted CURA and sp oke with Cameron Kerr to conduct cleanup procedures.

  • Description: On July 23,2024, TAG inspected trailer MCKZ550219, booking SEA 1040763. This load sailed NB on the North Star voyage 24115 that departed Tacoma on 7/19/2024. Upon inspecting it, TAG found an undeclared hazardous item of 1 box of UN 1090 Acetone Class flammable liquid not marked as limited quantity. The trailer was placarded as limited quantity and should have been placarded as Class 3. This item not being manifested could cause the trailer to be stowed not according to the proper segregation requirements. The trailer sailed with undeclared hazardous material inside and was stowed on the Vessel.

item.title: Report I-2024070103
item.description:
Report I-2024070103

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-23T15:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-21
  • City: LEMONT
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNIVAR SOLUTIONS USA INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Trailer was loaded at Rowell in Willow Springs on 06/20/2024 with hydrochloric acid 28% and parked for the next day's delivery. On 6/21/2024, driver went to make delivery to customer in University Park, IL. Driver could not get valves to open due to an issue with the air switches not fully opening the internal valve. This is when the trailer was brought to B&R for repairs. When the driver arrived at B&R he stopped and went into the office to check the trailer in, he came out and found HCL leaking from the pump cabinet onto the ground. Driver immediately went to seek out the source of the leak he found it to be leaking from a flange in the piping from the internal valve to the pump. He stopped the leak and began the neutralization process and reported it the repair shop. The repair shop helped the driver to neutralize the spill and clean it up. Driver estimated 5-8 gallons of hydrochloric acid 28% was lost. Trailer's leak was stopped, and the trailer was brought to a contained area to be pumped out. Once the trailer was emptied it was washed out and brought in for necessary repairs. It was found the secondary and internal valve failed. It was also found the flange gasket from the internal to the pump was the incorrect material.

  • Description: On 8/15/2024 at approxmately 1250, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 3646245 at the station location in Bedford Heights, reporting a dangerous goods material spill. The shipment consisted of 3 fiberboard boxes, each containing 1 metal can. The shipment arrived at the destination station, emitting a slight odor. Further inspection revealed that one the packages in the shipment had slightly spilled from the closure. The entire shipment is being held for pick-up by the reciepient.

  • City: HUBER HEIGHTS

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hepaco was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted the trailer floor and estimated that approximately five (5) gallons of material released due to five (5) 5-gallon metal pails that were crushed during transit. Hepaco personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and collected the spent absorbents and containerized it into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. The five (5) damaged pails were placed into five 10-gallon metal drums. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freights contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report X-2024081307
item.description:
Report X-2024081307

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-22T18:16:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-09
  • City: EARTH CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: FULLY LABELED HAZ-MAT SHIPMENT WAS VISUALLY DISCOVERED WET IN APPEARANCE AND EMITTING A PUNGENT ODOR BY AN UNLOADER IN SECTION-D. WITHOUT TOUCHING THE PKG HE EVACUATED THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR. DMP WAS CONTACTED AND WITHIN 2 MINUTES A DESIGNATED RESPONDER ARRIVED, DONNING THE PROPER PPE AND WITH A FULLY STOCKED SPILL CART. AFTER FOLLOWING THE DECISION TREE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET, THE DAMAGE WAS CONTAINED (NO SPILLAGE OUTSIDE OF CARTON), THEN TRANSPORTED TO THE DMP PROCESSING AREA. CLOSER INSPECTION REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON 1 OF 4 POLY 1-GAL JUGS WAS LOOSE BY 1/2 ROTATION, CAUSING APPROX. 12 OUNCES OF THE LIQUID PRODUCT TO LEAK THROUGH THE BREACH AND SATURATE THE CARTON. THE INTERNAL PACKING MATERIAL CONSISTED OF A SINGLE CURROGATED DIVIDER AND THE OUTER CARTON WAS A DOUBLEWALL FIBERBOARD BOX, RATED AT A 51 LBS/IN EDGE CRUSH TEST (ECT).

  • Description: On August 6, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon container of ZeroTol 2.0 was damaged and released approximately its full contents to the trailer interior and concrete below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from American Safety (AS) to remediate the impacted site. AS personnel noted the release had previously been remediated by RLC personnel. AS personnel collected the one (1) empty damaged 5-gallon container of ZeroTol 2.0 and containerized it into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum as waste. AS personnel then collected the cleanup debris and containerized it into the one (1) 55-gallon poly drum as well. All ZeroTol 2.0 impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon poly drum that was staged on-site

  • Description: Spill & exposure. Leaking box. One of 4x64oz plastic bottles Santeen Drain Cleaner lost 36oz from severe denting & loose cap closure. Spill occurred in spite of tape around caps & slotted partitions. Exposure: Package handler Jason Bowers, was exposed (skin contact on hands, no spotting or staining. Spillage released heat.) when attempting to remove package from IC belt. Package Handler Trainer Justin Hoeh had minor corrosion to undersides of shoes. Upon recommendation of Hoeh and Hall (DGNav reporter), the Work Area Manager ensured Bowers rinsed his hands for 10-15 min and continued follow up. Safety specialists have been notified.

item.title: Report I-2024080044
item.description:
Report I-2024080044

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-22T18:16:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-11
  • City: LAKE HAVASU CITY
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ECOLOGY CONTROL INDUSTRIES, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 11th, 2024 I drove a load from Marathon Refinery in Carson, CA to Foreman, AR. When I reached Lake Havasa, AZ it was a temperature of 125 degrees F. I reached the truck stop Pilots in Lake Havasa to take a 30 minute break and did a trailer inspection on the trailer 1145. I noticed the trailer was leaking the product out of the top of the tank. I rushed to grab some trash cans that the truck stop had next to my trailer to catch any liquid that was draining down the side of the tank. I climbed up the ladder to inspect where the leak was coming from and noticed it was leaking from the ARV Valve and also had 40 PSI of pressure and nowhere to relieve the pressure from. I cleaned up the tank and kept an eye on it and waited for temps to cool down. Once the temps cooled down I was able to relieve the pressure from the domes by cracking one of the ears. All the pressure was relieved and the leak stopped and was contained until the HAZMAT team showed up at 0900 in the morning to clean up.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-21T15:13:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-08
  • City: MIDDLETOWN
  • State: PA

  • Description: HAZMAT RESPONDER CLEANED UP PACKAGE AT BOTTOM OF SLIDE AND TRANSPORTED TO DMP CAGE. RESPONDER, WEARING FULL PPE, READ DECISION TREE AND RESPONSE SHEET FOR A FLAMMABLE LIQUID 3 PACKAGE. NO FREE LIQUID WAS IN DAMAGE, SO NO PH TAPE NEEDED. CONTAINED ALL OF THE DAMAGE AND PROCESSED THROUGH THE DMP. REFERRED TO WASTE DISPOSAL CHART FOR DISPOSITION AND DECONTAMINATION CHECKLIST.

item.title: Report X-2024081248
item.description:
Report X-2024081248

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-21T15:13:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-08
  • City: EARTH CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: FULLY LABELED HAZ-MAT SHIPMENT WAS VISUALLY DISCOVERED WET IN APPEARANCE BY AN UNLOADER IN SECTION-C. WITHOUT TOUCHING THE PKG SHE EVACUATED THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HER SUPERVISOR. DMP WAS CONTACTED AND WITHIN 2 MINUTES A DESIGNATED RESPONDER ARRIVED, DONNING THE PROPER PPE AND WITH A FULLY STOCKED SPILL CART. AFTER FOLLOWING THE DECISION TREE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET, THE DAMAGE WAS CONTAINED (NO SPILLAGE OUTSIDE OF CARTON), THEN TRANSPORTED TO THE DMP PROCESSING AREA. CLOSER INSPECTION REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON 1 OF 4 POLY 1-GAL JUGS WAS LOOSE BY 1/2 ROTATION, CAUSING APPROX. 12 OUNCES OF THE LIQUID PRODUCT TO SPILL THROUGH THE BREACH AND INTO THE CARTON. THERE WAS NO INTERNAL PACKING MATERIAL AND THE OUTER CARTON WAS A DOUBLEWALL FIBERBOARD BOX, RATED AT A 51 LBS/IN EDGE CRUSH TEST (ECT).

item.title: Report X-2024081224
item.description:
Report X-2024081224

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-21T15:13:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-05
  • City: Waterloo
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Chicago Central And Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 17910
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Monday, August 5, 2024, a CN mechanical performing an inspection observed that the bottom outlet valve appeared to be leaking from tank car # FURX 160111 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Waterloo Yard Master who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The tank car was set out to an isolation track (WA60) for inspection by a CN emergency response contractor. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location for mitigation. The contractor performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap. It was determined that there was a failure in the sealing surface of the valve seat to include a defective gasket. (The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight and the BOV in the closed position and pinned upon initial inspection). CN emergency response contractor did observe cable seal to be correctly in place. The BOV cap was removed, and it was observed to be leaking past the closed ball. The BOV valve handle was cycled several times to the open and closed position to free any debris that may have been trapped in the BOV sealing surface potentially causing the leak. The BOV cap was then removed and observed for 20 minutes to ensure there was no further leakage from the valve. It was noted that the BOV cap gasket was deformed and was replaced. The bottom outlet valve cap was then re-installed and tightened with a 36" pipe wrench. Upon tightening the BOV cap, CN emergency response contractor proceeded to place new cable seals on the BOV / Cap.

item.title: Report E-2024080435
item.description:
Report E-2024080435

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T18:16:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-15
  • City: CHASKA
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During a customer site pickup, an incident occurred involving a drum of Isopropanol. A Veolia employee was reorganizing the box truck when the accident happened. While using a drum cart to relocate the Isopropanol container, the drum was improperly secured and fell backwards onto the cart. As a result, one of the cart's forks punctured the drum. The puncture caused approximately 2 gallons of Isopropanol to spill. Prompt action was taken to address the situation. The spilled material was thoroughly cleaned up and disposed of in accordance with proper procedures. To prevent further leakage, the damaged drum was placed inside an overpack container.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Tuesday, July 23, 2024, at 08:39 hours, a CSX Mechanical Manager reported an odor in the area of PROX 99823, a loaded tank car of Anhydrous Ammonia. The car was isolated and the shipper, PCS Sales, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2024-0723-00094). Marion Environmental, Inc. (MEI), a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and confirmed anon-accident release due to the B end liquid line valve partially open and secondary closure plug not properly installed. Contractor personnel closed the liquid line valve and resecured the valves closure plug. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shippers representative- Matt Painter (706-564-8118). At the request of the FRA, the car was held pending OTMA.

item.title: Report E-2024080448
item.description:
Report E-2024080448

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T18:16:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-19
  • City: SAINT LOUIS
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 19, 2024, at 2034 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by XPO personnel in Saint Louis, Missouri regarding the release of Kem-Tek Pool & Spa Care Swimming Pool Muriatic Acid (UN1789, Hydrochloric Acid Solution, 8, III). Hepaco contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all cleanup activities. Upon the arrival, contractors confirmed the release of a total of 2 gallons from (2) 1-gallon plastic jugs of material. The release impacted a pallet, 5 other boxes of cargo, and a 8ft-by-8ft area of the concrete dock floor due to a forklift puncture. Contractors neutralized and cleaned the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. The undamaged cargo was removed from the damaged boxes and placed in (1) 55-gallon DF to be forwarded to the original consignee. The damaged boxes, pallet, and spent absorbents were containerized in (2) 55-gallon DF's as waste and staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 13, 2024, at 0457 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by XPO personnel in La Salle, Arkansas regarding the release of Micronic 725 S (UN3266 Corrosive Liquid, Basic, inorganic, n.o.s., 8, II). Hepaco contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors observed approximately 2 ounces released from (1) 275-gallon IBC plastic tote. The release was caused by a loose cap and impacted the top of the tote and cardboard. Contractors wiped down the impacted area and tightened the cap. The spent rags and impacted cardboard was placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum and staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal. approximately (2) ounces of CRW 9220 Corrosion Inhibitor (Flammable liquid, toxic, n.o.s., (Methanol, Isopropanol), UN1992, 3, 6.1, III) from (7) 55-gallon poly drums. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed that the release was contained to the tops of the drums only, contractors wiped down the totes and tightened the drum caps so the cargo could be forwarded on to the original consignee. All waste generated was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal. IF NO RELEASE Contractors were unable to locate any damaged cargo. No waste was generated from this event.

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver made reversed hose connections to tractor mounted product pump. This caused the pump to draft from the receiving AST and into the transport trailer, ultimately overfilling the compartment, filling the vapor system, and releasing to the ground. The compartment dome lid was forced up due to pressure releasing larger amount until pump could be stopped. Product flowed by natura gravity to a retention pond adjacent to the AST delivery area. Lewis Environmental responded for remediation of ground and affected water retention pond.

  • City: Petersburg

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 1/5/24 at approximately 10:00 AM, Operators were loading ethanol from railcar MUI-X 730192 into Petroleum Carriers trailer 9301. While loading a scheduled 1400 gallons into compartment 2(capacity 2500 gallons), product. was released from the overflow tubes at the rear of the trailer. The pump 0meter read 1272 gallons at the time of the release. An estimated 100 gallons impacted the asphalt. Product evaporated, there is no cleanup material to be disposed of. All appropriate personnel were notified of the incident. Overfill protection on the pump was disabled by the loaders. Driver failed to advise loaders that there was product remaining in the compartment being loaded.

  • Description: Fifteen minutes after departing from BOS, the customer observed their crossbody bag that they were wearing smelled strongly of the e-cigarette juice. Upon opening the zipper compartment holding the e-cigarette he saw the blue light on and was unable to switch it off. The customer immediately notified a Flight Attendant to assist with the situation. The Purser obtained the e-cigarette and utilized the fire containment bag. The crew maintained custody of the containment bag until arrival in LAX when it was tendered to the CSM who met the flight.

item.title: Report I-2024010053
item.description:
Report I-2024010053

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-12
  • City: Charlotte
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Passenger Drake Cox informed us of his laptop overheating inside of his backpack. When we got out the fire containment bag, he decided to bring the whole backpack to us. We put on the heat resistant gloves and a second Flight Attendant helped me with pouring a Iiter of water on the inside of the fire containment bag. I removed the laptop from the backpack and placed it in the fire containment bag with the battery facing down. The second Flight Attendant cleared out a galley cart and we placed the fire containment bag in the furthest aircraft right galley cart in the AFT of the aircraft. We continued to monitor the laptop throughout the rest of the flight, but no further action was needed. Once we arrived and all the passengers deplaned, the entire cart was brought to the forward galley as per the Supervisofs request and that's when the Supervisor told us Flight Attendants we were ok to leave and the rest would be taken care of. The laptop was an Apple MacBook Pro.

item.title: Report E-2024080373
item.description:
Report E-2024080373

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-13
  • City: CONLEY
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROADRUNNER TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On August 13, 2024, at 2050 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Conley, Georgia regarding the release of Socar Brake Wash (UN1208, Hexanes, 3, II). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 20 gallons of Socar Brake Wash (UN1208, Hexanes, 3, II) from (1) 55-gallon DM. The release was caused by a forklift puncture and impacted a 15ft x 20ft area of concrete on the dock floor. Contractors reported that the release had completely evaporated by the time they arrived. Contractors placed the damaged drum with the remaining product into a 65-gallon metal overpack then staged the waste onsite for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024080369
item.description:
Report E-2024080369

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-12
  • City: EAST SAINT LOUIS
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On August 12, 2024, at 1321 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in East St. Louis, Illinois regarding the release of Eterset 2950 (UN1866, Resin Solution, 3, III). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 5 ounces of ETERSET 2950 from (1) 55-gallon DM that impacted a 5ft x 5ft area of the trailer floor. Contractors could not determine the cause of the release. Contractors placed the damaged drum with residual product in an overpack to be forwarded on to the original consignee, then cleaned the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste was containerized in (1) 5-gallon DF and taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Description: Package came out of trailer 830928 in a wet state. Package was placed in a tote for QA. Upon inspection, contents are 4 bottles of isopropyl alcohol, with 1 bottle having a loose cap, causing its liquid contents to spill out. No protection for caps or prevention from bottles from moving was the likely cause of the cap becoming loose. Better inner packing for both bottles and caps would help prevent caps from becoming loose.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-07
  • City: DENVER
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During sort operations at the DENR location a fiberboard box was found with signs of a release. While investigating the fiberboard box the spill agent found a plastic bucket and a plastic bottle inside. Packaged in plastic bags with packing paper for dunnage. The cap was loose of the plastic bottle causing it to spill all of the contents. The plastic bottle had a flammable liquid DG marking on it but no other labeling. There were no DG making or paperwork on the outside of the fiberboard box. All contents were placed into a steel salvage package and are being held at the location.

item.title: Report E-2024080384
item.description:
Report E-2024080384

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-05
  • City: WEST DES MOINES
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 95000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On August 5, 2024, at 1631 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Des Moines, Iowa regarding the release of Lactic Acid (UN3265, 8, III). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of Lactic Acid (UN3265, Corrosive Liquid, acidic, organic, n.o.s., 8, III) from (9) 275-gallon IBC plastic totes. The release was caused by a rollover accident and impacted the trailer floor, and an area of soil. Contractors placed neutralizer and absorbents on the soil in preparation for remedial and restorative activities, and the totes and trailer were transported to a nearby tow facility. At the tow facility there was an additional release of material that impacted a trail of concrete and the inside of a roll-off. Contractors neutralized, and cleaned all impacted areas with absorbents, then transferred the remaining product from the damaged totes into new totes. All waste was collected and containerized in (11) 55-gallon DFs and (9) 275-gallon IBC plastic totes, then staged onsite for proper disposal.

  • Description: E3OMI was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted two (2) 3ft-by-2ft area of the trailer floor and the concrete floor and estimated that one (1) gallon of material was released due to forklift damaging two (2) 5-gallon metal pails. E3OMI personnel deployed absorbent pads to recover the released material. E3OMI personnel placed the two (2) damaged pails into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum and the spent absorbent pads, impacted cardboard and PPE into one (1) additional 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: Southwest Airlines F3204 departed Chicago Midway Airport(MDW) in route to Miami International Airport (MIA) but diverted to West Palm Beach Airport(PBI). On final decent into MIA about 25 minutes until landing when we experienced a fire and smoke on board froni a cell phone and power bank. Flight attendants used the on board fire containment bag and safety measures. Aircraft terminated in PBI and passengers were re-accommodated to MIA. Pictures available upon request. SWA FAA PHI David Evans and FAA Hazardous Material Aviation Safety Inspector Santos L Garcia have been provided pictures and information.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • City: GAFFNEY
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On August 2, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1760 was crushed in transit and released approximately thirty (30) gallons of product to the trailer interior, surrounding cargo asphalt, and nearby catch basin. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. A drum head vacuum was used to collect and containerize approximately 100 gallons of UN1760 impacted water from the catch basin of the storm drain into two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal. It was determined that the product remained contained to the catch basin and did not migrate or threaten to impact any waters of the state. Granular absorbents, absorbent pads, and neutralizer were used to remediate the impacted surfaces. The damaged drum was overpacked into one (1) 85 gallons drum for disposal purposes. All UN1760 impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal purposes.

All UN3266 impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum which was staged onsite.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 25, 2024, three (3) 55-gallon drums of UN2922 waste spilled in transit due to improper containment. As a result, the drums released approximately fifteen (15) gallons of product to the trailer interior, which further migrated to the parking lot below. Freehold Cartage retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental (ME) to remediate the impacted site. ME personnel utilized a vacuum pump to transfer product to a new 55-gallon poly drum. Crews worked to contain the release underneath and around the exterior of the trailer. ME personnel secured the site and scheduled to return at a later date for additional remedial operations. On July 26, 2024, a crew from ME returned to the site for additional remediation. ME personnel utilized a pallet jack to transfer the undamaged freight to the trailer for normal transport. All UN2922 impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LWA experienced a UN1789 Blue Whale Muriatic Acid release. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 4-gallons of product released to a 4' x 4' area of the trailer floor and a 4' x 4' area of concrete underneath the trailer. The release was caused due to the pallet collapsing possibly as a result of stacking. The impacted boxes and jugs were removed from the pallet. The impacted areas were then cleaned with absorbents and sodium bicarbonate. All impacted absorbents, debris, and damaged containers were collected into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: July 8, 2024: On this date a driver for LPG Logistics USDOT 3142354 (C Three Logistics USDOT 2961868) was delivering the above listed material to a client in Berlin NJ. The Driver and receiver's operator failed to ensure the hose was empty of product prior to disconnecting the hose. The material within the hose ( Approx 5-20 gallons) spilled on the ground. The area was immediately secured. The product was contained with dry absorbent and absorbing pads and properly disposed of via an authorized recovery company. The report is being submitted at the request of the manufacturer/shipper. No injuries, deaths, fire, waterway involvement. NRC notified on 7-9-24 NRC # 1404204. NJDEP 24-07-09-1610-25 (Closed)

item.title: Report I-2024080001
item.description:
Report I-2024080001

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-03
  • City: Greenville
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: federal express corporation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Bulk Truck#205997 was put on door. There was a foul odor coming from the vehicle which smelled like vinegar. The bulk truck was pulled off the door and parked in the yard with the back door left open in order to air it out. Later during the sort, the bulk truck was put back on door however the odor did not dissipate. Once some packages were pulled out, the spill was evident. Blue dye was all over the floor on the right side of the vehicle. A(formerly) white pail was on its side with the top cap open. The pail was covered in blue dye which covered the label and any other information. We started pulling out the leaked-on packages and came across a second white pail which was identical to the first and listed as 1 of 2. Upon inspection, a Corrosive Class 8 diamond label was discovered on the side of the pail. There were SDS sheets attached to the pail. Also on the pail was a manufacturing label which listed UN#, DOT shipping name of material, Technical name, Hazardous Class and Packing Group. No Hazardous Materials Certification Form was submitted, no OP-900LL on the pail and there was no"HAZ" marking on the FXG shipping label. The shipper shipped this as an Undeclared Hazmat(TRACKING#777176962630). This shipment was classified as a PGI. Since we were dealing with a high danger hazmat and all 6 gallons had spilled out, it was determined that any intemal attempt at cleanup was beyond our capabilities and this incident needed to be reported. My first call was to the Emergency Spill number listed on the container which is required of the shipper. The company listed was CHEMTREC 1-800-424-9300. I filed a spill incident report with them and received a report number(#224070300268). They then instructed me to contact our company's Emergency Spill Response Service. The spill met the criteria listed for our FXG Emergency Spill Response Service 1-833-394-7745. Once contacted, I provided them with all the information that they required, and they assigned Alert#212661 to our request for assistance. They dispatched a cleanup team and instructed me to meet them when they arrived as well as remain on site during the cleanup process.

item.title: Report I-2024070114
item.description:
Report I-2024070114

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-24
  • City: EAST CHICAGO
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: TRADEBE TRANSPORTATION LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 24, 2024 a Tradebe Transportation driver made a customer pickup at the customer's location: Chem Processing INC, 3910 Linden Oaks Drive, Rockford, IL. After the driver returned to Tradebe Treatment and Recycling at 4343 Kennedy Avenue, East Chicago, IN the receiving supervisor noted that one of the totes was empty and that 200-250 gallons of material in the tote was released, It was determined that the material loaded in behind the tote shifted in transit and damaged the bottom valve causing the material to spill. The overall root cause was that the load was not blocked and braced properly.

  • Description: Driver arrived at delivery site to pump product into the above ground tank. When the tank filled to capacity the 90% shut off didn't work and allowed product to overfill into diked area. Driver immediately called dispatch office, dispatch called headquarters and spoke to Julie Jennings who then called Perdue Environmental Contracting Company, Inc. for Emergency Response and Clean-up. Call was placed to NRC and KYEPA to report the spill and clean-up efforts.
